update.description: Dockerfile and scripts for creating a Docker image for VMRC. Please, follow the instructions described in [this](#!/osrf/vmrc/wiki/tutorials/SystemSetup) tutorial.
update.title: Add docker utilities

content.raw: I’m merging, we’ll ticket an issue if something needs tweaking.
content.html: I’m merging, we’ll ticket an issue if something needs tweaking.

content.raw: The gamepad works for me. Doesn't work for you? I mounted `/dev/input` as a volume \(it’s already in this pull request\). Thanks for tweaking the tutorials!
content.html: The gamepad works for me. Doesn't work for you? I mounted /dev/input as a volume (it’s already in this pull request). Thanks for tweaking the tutorials!

content.raw:
I believe everything is working in Docker!  I’d propose the PR is ready to merge.

I made some edits/additions to the tutorial wikis.

I haven’t yet tackled how to get the gamepad to talk to the docker container - did we have instructions for that?

Nice work!!!
content.html:
I believe everything is working in Docker! I’d propose the PR is ready to merge.

I made some edits/additions to the tutorial wikis.

I haven’t yet tackled how to get the gamepad to talk to the docker container - did we have instructions for that?

Nice work!!!

content.raw: I think is the same problem described in issue #9. Note that `Docker`could be a little tricky in these situations because it will cache the command where you clone the VMRC repo, so it won’t be cloned again after merging the potential patch. I suggest to remove all lines after line 52, and clone and compile the workspace manually, to make sure that it fixes the issue. Then, you can restore the lines and rebuild.
content.html: I think is the same problem described in issue #9. Note that Dockercould be a little tricky in these situations because it will cache the command where you clone the VMRC repo, so it won’t be cloned again after merging the potential patch. I suggest to remove all lines after line 52, and clone and compile the workspace manually, to make sure that it fixes the issue. Then, you can restore the lines and rebuild.

content.raw:
Testing from home using a fairly new install of Ubuntu GNOME 16.04 \(no ROS/Gazebo installed on the host!\) Following the tutorial wiki.

At the docker build step I run into this error

Could be related to this issue [#!/osrf/vmrc/issues/9/cmake-error-with-usvdriveh](#!/osrf/vmrc/issues/9/cmake-error-with-usvdriveh)

I tried running multiple times to see if that took care of the error.

‌

Also tried skipping to the run step to see if I could go ahead and run the container and got another error…

    brian.bingham@Laptop-Brian:~/vmrc_docker$ ./run.bash vmrc
    xauth:  file /tmp/.docker.xauth does not exist
    [sudo] password for brian.bingham: 
    Unable to find image 'vmrc:latest' locally
    docker: Error response from daemon: pull access denied for vmrc, repository does not exist or may require 'docker login'.
    See 'docker run --help'.
    

‌
content.html:

content.raw:
I haven’t fixed this yet, but have more information and a start on a troubleshooting section for the wiki. I’m going to see if Micheal can address it since he has experience working with Docker on the NPS network.

Should have a test in the setup wiki to test for network access and determine if there is a DNS problem

# Test Docker’s network access

    docker run busybox nslookup google.com

If the system returns something like…

    $ docker run busybox nslookup google.com
    Server:    172.20.20.11
    Address 1: 172.20.20.11 lee.ern.nps.edu
    
    Name:      google.com
    Address 1: 2607:f8b0:4005:804::200e sfo07s13-in-x0e.1e100.net
    Address 2: 216.58.195.78 sfo07s16-in-f78.1e100.net

then the system has network access and we can proceed with building the VMRC container.

If the system hangs for a long time \(~5 min\) and returns something like

    Server:    8.8.8.8
    Address 1: 8.8.8.8
    
    nslookup: can't resolve 'google.com'

then we have a network problem. The likely cause is that we can’t use the default DNS.

# Temporarily try using host’s DNS

First, let’s find out what DNS docker is using…

    docker run busybox less /etc/resolv.conf

which will generate something like…

    # Dynamic resolv.conf(5) file for glibc resolver(3) generated by resolvconf(8)
    #     DO NOT EDIT THIS FILE BY HAND -- YOUR CHANGES WILL BE OVERWRITTEN
    
    nameserver 8.8.8.8
    nameserver 8.8.4.4

Let’s compare that to the Host DNS. On the host

    $ nmcli dev show | grep 'IP4.DNS'
    IP4.DNS[1]:                             172.20.20.11
    IP4.DNS[2]:                             172.10.20.12

Now, let’s see if we can temporarily use the first DNS that our host uses…

    $ docker run --dns 172.20.20.11 busybox nslookup google.com
    Server:    172.20.20.11
    Address 1: 172.20.20.11 lee.ern.nps.edu
    
    Name:      google.com
    Address 1: 2607:f8b0:4005:807::200e sfo07s16-in-x0e.1e100.net
    Address 2: 216.58.195.78 sfo07s16-in-f78.1e100.net

# Configuring Docker to use host DNS

This would be the permanent fix. I haven’t made this work yet, but the two options I’ve found are…

1. Add the following lines to the `/etc/docker/daemon.json` file

    \{ "dns": \["172.20.20.11", "172.10.20.12"\] \}



2\) Add the following lines to the `/etc/default/docker` file

    # Use DOCKER_OPTS to modify the daemon startup options.
    DOCKER_OPTS="--dns 172.20.20.11 --dns 172.10.20.12"

In either case my test is to restart docker \(`sudo service docker restart`\) and then either check the DNS from within the container `docker run busybox less /etc/resolv.conf` or to try to do a lookup `docker run busybox nslookup google.com` - the former is much faster.

References:

* [https://stackoverflow.com/questions/24151129/docker-network-calls-fail-during-image-build-on-corporate-network](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/24151129/docker-network-calls-fail-during-image-build-on-corporate-network)
* [https://development.robinwinslow.uk/2016/06/23/fix-docker-networking-dns/](https://development.robinwinslow.uk/2016/06/23/fix-docker-networking-dns/)

So far no luck getting docker to recognize the hard coded DNS.

‌
content.html:
I haven’t fixed this yet, but have more information and a start on a troubleshooting section for the wiki. I’m going to see if Micheal can address it since he has experience working with Docker on the NPS network.

Should have a test in the setup wiki to test for network access and determine if there is a DNS problem

Test Docker’s network access

docker run busybox nslookup google.com

If the system returns something like…

$ docker run busybox nslookup google.com
Server:    172.20.20.11
Address 1: 172.20.20.11 lee.ern.nps.edu

Name:      google.com
Address 1: 2607:f8b0:4005:804::200e sfo07s13-in-x0e.1e100.net
Address 2: 216.58.195.78 sfo07s16-in-f78.1e100.net

then the system has network access and we can proceed with building the VMRC container.

If the system hangs for a long time (~5 min) and returns something like

Server:    8.8.8.8
Address 1: 8.8.8.8

nslookup: can't resolve 'google.com'

then we have a network problem. The likely cause is that we can’t use the default DNS.

Temporarily try using host’s DNS

First, let’s find out what DNS docker is using…

docker run busybox less /etc/resolv.conf

which will generate something like…

# Dynamic resolv.conf(5) file for glibc resolver(3) generated by resolvconf(8)
#     DO NOT EDIT THIS FILE BY HAND -- YOUR CHANGES WILL BE OVERWRITTEN

nameserver 8.8.8.8
nameserver 8.8.4.4

Let’s compare that to the Host DNS. On the host

$ nmcli dev show | grep 'IP4.DNS'
IP4.DNS[1]:                             172.20.20.11
IP4.DNS[2]:                             172.10.20.12

Now, let’s see if we can temporarily use the first DNS that our host uses…

$ docker run --dns 172.20.20.11 busybox nslookup google.com
Server:    172.20.20.11
Address 1: 172.20.20.11 lee.ern.nps.edu

Name:      google.com
Address 1: 2607:f8b0:4005:807::200e sfo07s16-in-x0e.1e100.net
Address 2: 216.58.195.78 sfo07s16-in-f78.1e100.net

Configuring Docker to use host DNS

This would be the permanent fix. I haven’t made this work yet, but the two options I’ve found are…

  1. Add the following lines to the /etc/docker/daemon.json file

    { "dns": ["172.20.20.11", "172.10.20.12"] }

2) Add the following lines to the /etc/default/docker file

# Use DOCKER_OPTS to modify the daemon startup options.
DOCKER_OPTS="--dns 172.20.20.11 --dns 172.10.20.12"

In either case my test is to restart docker (sudo service docker restart) and then either check the DNS from within the container docker run busybox less /etc/resolv.conf or to try to do a lookup docker run busybox nslookup google.com - the former is much faster.

References:

  • https://stackoverflow.com/questions/24151129/docker-network-calls-fail-during-image-build-on-corporate-network
  • https://development.robinwinslow.uk/2016/06/23/fix-docker-networking-dns/

So far no luck getting docker to recognize the hard coded DNS.

‌

Yep - I think I have the solution, but still refining.    Seems to be fixable at least a couple ways.   Seems common enough that we should have a troubleshooting section?

‌
